summary: This is an FBI 302 interview report of a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) employee who was in charge of cameras at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) at the time of Jeffrey Epstein's death. The employee details the poor state of the camera system, including multiple failures leading up to and on August 10, 2019, and describes the process of attempting to rebuild the DVR after the incident, noting an FBI agent was involved in removing the hard drives.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate who died at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 10, 2019; the interviewee was one of the personnel who briefly tried to resuscitate him.

events.title: DVR 2 System Failure
events.description: The camera system's DVR 2 experienced a system failure at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: DVR 2 Motherboard Failure
events.description: The motherboard on DVR 2 of the camera system failed at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Hard Drive Failure and Epstein Death
events.description: The hard drive on the camera system failed. A body alarm sounded around 6am, and Jeffrey Epstein was found deceased. Personnel, including the interviewee, responded and attempted resuscitation.

events.title: FBI Interview of BOP Employee
events.description: An unnamed Bureau of Prisons employee was interviewed by an Assistant United States Attorney and law enforcement agents regarding the camera system and events surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death.

locations: United States Attorneys Office (USAO), Southern District of New York (SDNY), 1 St. Andrews Plaza, New York, New York
keyFacts: The camera system at the Metropolitan Correctional Center was over 20 years old, analog, poorly maintained, and frequently malfunctioned.
At the time of Jeffrey Epstein's death on August 10, 2019, only one hard drive of the camera system was working.
Multiple failures occurred in the camera system's DVR 2 in late July and early August 2019, culminating in a hard drive failure on August 10.
After the incident, an FBI agent was the one who physically removed the DVR containing the failed hard drives from the system.
Replacing the failed hard drives would have wiped all prior recorded data from the camera system.
